section-block.rac_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Mike Wohnoutka
section-block.rac_book_summary: You will learn all about what happened first, second, third, fourth, and last in this story about how Oliver’s dad handled Oliver’s first day of school.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ordinal numbers tell the order that things are arranged in. Ask three children to stand in a line. Point to the first child and have children say first. Repeat with the next numbers.
Ask, What do you do first thing in the morning? Ask children to stand and share their answers. Guide children to use complete sentences: The first thing I do in the morning is ___ .

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Dad’s First Day by Mike Wohnoutka. What could it be Dad’s first day of?
You remember Lala—she loves to read! She is excited to read this narrative, or story.
I am going to ask you a question. We’ll talk about it after we read.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Dad feel about the first day of school?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Use location words to ask children to point to images in the book.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see the word first. Oliver has never been to school before, so it will be his first day.
How do you think Oliver feels about his first day of school? Why does Oliver’s dad feel a little nervous?
Where is Oliver’s dad hiding? Why do you think he keeps hiding?
Poor Dad. Why does his tummy hurt so much?
How does Oliver’s dad feel about school now? Why do their tummies hurt? Are they still nervous?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Dad feel about the first day of school?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Dad feels very nervous about the first day of school.
Dad feels sad that Oliver isn’t home with him.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about the first day of school as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What feeling makes Dad’s tummy hurt?
Dad feels nervous about the first day of school.
Do Dad’s feelings change by the end of the story?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children naturally use ordinal numbers to describe line order, turn-taking, and other daily routines and behaviors. Help children learn ordinal numbers by teaching them in the context of their lives. When children are lined up to leave the classroom, ask them to identify who is first, second, third, fourth, and fifth in line.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Tolerate Frustration
section-block.rac_body-text: Frustration is part of the learning process. Help children grow by teaching them strategies to overcome frustration. Encourage them not to give up, even if they fail. They can ask for help from someone. Trying a new approach or taking a break might help children tolerate frustration.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread Dad’s First Day by Mike Wohnoutka and look closer at parts of the book. We will think about how Oliver’s dad tolerated frustration and got used to change.
Clifford knows that being frustrated can sometimes be helpful, even if it feels bad. Instead of getting angry and giving up, Clifford knows that he can learn from these experiences.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Ask children to think about what happened first, second, and third to practice using ordinal numbers.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Oliver’s dad is feeling nervous, which is another word for worried. Why is Daddy worried?
Where did Oliver’s dad hide? Point out the location words: behind, inside, and outside.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Where did Dad hide first? Second? Third?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Oliver do when he first got to school? What happened second?
Oliver’s dad looks like he feels upset and frustrated. Why would he feel frustrated? What does Dad want to do that he can’t? (MB)
What did Oliver’s dad see when he looked in the classroom? What made Oliver’s dad stop feeling frustrated? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Gather objects or pictures to represent parts of the daily schedule, for instance a kickball for gym or a book for reading time. Ask children to name each activity and then place the objects or signs in sequential order. Guide children to use ordinal numbers as they discuss which activity comes first, second, third, etc.
Transcribe children’s memories of their first day of school.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help children learn to make and keep relationships with peers and trusted adults. Guide children to cultivate these relationships by calling friends and adults by name, learning about their lives, and noticing when they are absent. One practical application of this Mind Builder is to help children plan something special for a parent’s or friend’s birthday.

section-block.rac_body-text: Play a quick game of “I Spy” in which you describe an object in the room using location words. Guide children to guess which object you are talking about.
Sing the classic song Going on a Bear Hunt to review location words like over, under, and through. Encourage children to use hand motions to act out the lyrics.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Dad’s First Day by Mike Wohnoutka.
Lala loves reading narrative books, or stories.
As we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can you tell that Oliver’s dad feels nervous?

section.rac_body-text: Help children understand concepts of time by pointing out how time passes in the story.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Summer lasts for 3 months—that’s almost 100 days! You can do a lot during that time. What did Oliver and his dad do during the summer? Did you do any of those activities during the summer?

This page shows Oliver and his dad getting ready the night before school. That means summer is over and Oliver starts school the next morning. How do you think Oliver and his dad feel? How can you tell?
Now it’s the morning of the first day of school. How does Dad feel now?
Uh oh. Dad keeps hiding. Why do you think Dad is wasting time? When have you done something like this before?
Oliver finally got to school! How do you think Oliver and Dad feel now? Do they feel the same about school?
What did Oliver’s dad do while Oliver is at school to pass the time? How was he feeling?
Oliver and his dad celebrated the end of the first day of school. How did Oliver’s dad feel at the end of the day? Why does he feel differently at the end of the story?
Did you listen carefully to the story? How can you tell that Oliver’s dad feels nervous?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Oliver’s dad’s tummy hurt the whole day.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about all of the activities children can do during one day.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What feelings does Oliver’s dad’s show by hiding?
Oliver’s dad kept h_____ (hiding) because he was nervous.
Oliver’s dad kept hiding because he was nervous about school.
Why did Oliver’s dad change his mind at the end of the story?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children’s school schedules and daily activities vary widely by country. In France and China for example, children go home to eat lunch with their families and then return for the afternoon. Encourage an appreciation of other countries’ cultures by sharing information about schools around the world.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in discussing Oliver’s school and comparing it to theirs. Can they find pictures of things they do or don’t do at school?
Help children get their wiggles out by playing Freeze Dance! Play a song and invite the children to dance. When you freeze (pause) the song, they freeze (stop dancing) too.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Our School Rules. It is an informational poster about school rules.
Dad’s First Day and Our School Rules are both about what children do at school. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Dad’s First Day book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s think about how this poster connects to our concept question:
What do we do at school?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart of Big Ideas, stopping to ask these questions. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We share so much in school! What do you share every day in school?
When do we clean up in our classroom? Why is cleaning up important?
When is it important to take turns? How is it helpful to take turns?
How do we show we are listening? Who do we listen to? Why is listening important?
How do we stay safe in school? Who is at school to help us stay safe?
What does it mean to be kind? Why should we be kind to each other? How does being kind help us make and keep friends?

section.rac_body-text: Share arts and crafts materials that children can use to draw, color, and paint pictures to help decorate the school. Encourage children to make pictures of their favorite people, places, or activities in school.
Provide a writing prompt about what happens each day at school and provide feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Share some reasons with children why schools have rules. Help children understand that schools and classrooms use rules to keep children safe, healthy, and happy. Effective rules promote learning and allow children to grow and experiment in a safe space.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask, What did you do this morning before you came to school? Encourage children to use time words and ordinal numbers to describe their day so far.
(Tune: “You Are My Sunshine”)In the morning, I wake up happy, The sun is bright and I go to school. Then when night falls, I go to sleepUntil tomorrow comes.
Review words that will be helpful again today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Dad’s First Day one more time this week.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches information. Which is it?
We have learned a lot about Oliver and his Dad’s feelings about the first day of school. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can you tell how the people you know are feeling?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time together. This time, we’ll act out certain parts of the book.
What happens first on these two pages? Let’s pretend to throw a ball like Oliver’s dad!
What happens third? Who can sing like Oliver?
Dad says his tummy hurts! We know that means he’s nervous. What else does Dad do to show he’s nervous?
Let’s pretend to be nervous! We can hold our stomachs tight.
Oliver and his dad are inside the car. Where is Oliver sitting? Is he behind or next to his dad?
Let’s pretend we are driving very slowly to school.
What is happening in the first picture? Dad’s face looks sad.
Dad’s face changes a little in each picture. Is he still sad in the fourth picture? Was Dad hugging Oliver for only a little while, or for a long time? How can you tell?
Let’s pretend to hug someone very tight!
Oliver and his dad are celebrating! How can you tell Dad is happy now?
Let’s pretend to celebrate! We can cheer and smile to show we are very happy.
How can you tell how the people you know are feeling?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then ask several children to share with the group.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I can listen to what they say.
I can watch what they do.
I can look at their face.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about their first week of school and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What body part can you look at to know how someone’s feeling?
I can look at someone’s f_____ (face).
I can look at someone’s face.
What can you do when you know someone feels nervous?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Understanding the Passage of Time
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschool children are still learning the concept of time. They don’t think of a day as something that passes in hours and minutes. Instead, they mark time by events. It is important at this age to develop and discuss routines wherever possible. A routine gives children a way to talk about and predict each day more easily.
